Diagnosis/Problems


Diagnosis/Problems





(1) Acute heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and diastolic dysfunction


Assessment & Plan:  Symptomatically improved.  She is on carvedilol, Entresto 

and spironolactone.





(2) Cardiomyopathy


Assessment & Plan:  Her most recent previous echocardiogram from 2021 showed 

mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction.  Now she has severe left ventricular

systolic dysfunction.  She may need an ischemic evaluation once she recovers 

from her COVID.  We may also want to consider a LifeVest prior to discharge.





(3) Primary hypertension


Assessment & Plan:  Blood pressure is reasonably controlled with the present 

combination of medications.  If anything, at times she is running on the low 

side.





(4) Mixed hyperlipidemia


Assessment & Plan:  It appears as though she may have been on both atorvastatin 

and fenofibrate at home.  I will resume the atorvastatin.  I will hold off on 

restarting fenofibrate due to her acute debility with potentially increased risk

for medication interactions between the atorvastatin and fenofibrate.

Physical Therapy


Patient came to rehab with covid 19 debility.  Upon evaluation patient performs 

rolling and supine <-> sit with independence, sit <-> stand min assist, 

transfers CGA, car transfer CGA, ambulate 50' with a rolling walker with CGA (

including 50' with at least 2 turns of 90 degrees), can go up and down 1 step 

using a rolling walker with CGA.  Patient has been performing bed mobility and 

transfer training, balance and endurance training, functional strengthening, 

stair training, gait training, and education.  Patient has made fair progress 

but has not met her long term goals for distance of ambulation and number of 

stairs.  Now, patient performs rolling and supine <-> sit with independence, sit

<-> stand and transfers independent, ambulates 50' with a rolling walker with 

independence (including 50' with at least 2 turns of 90 degrees and 10' over an 

uneven surface), can go up and down 3 steps using a rolling walker with 

independence, and can pick up an object from the floor with independence.  

Patient is being discharged from this facility today and will be discharged from

PT at this time.

Therapy Code Descriptions/Definitions 





Functional Independence Measure:


0=Not Assessed/NA        4=Minimal Assistance


1=Total Assistance        5=Supervision or Setup


2=Maximal Assistance  6=Modified Independence


3=Moderate Assistance 7=Complete IndependenceSCALE: Activities may be completed 

with or without assistive devices.





6-Indepedent-patient completes the activity by him/herself with no assistance 

from a helper.


5-Set-up or Clean-up Assistance-helper sets up or cleans up; patient completes 

activity. **** assists only prior to ****  


    following the activity.


4-Supervision or Touching Assistance-helper provides verbal cues and/or 

touching/steadying and/or contact guard assistance as patient completes 

activity. Assistance may be provided   


    throughout the activity or intermittently.


3-Partial/Moderate Assistance-helper does LESS **** **** the effort. **** 

lifts, holds or supports trunk or limbs, but provides less than half the effort.


2-Substantial/Maximal Assistance-helper does MORE **** **** the effort. **** 

lifts or holds trunk or limbs and provides more than half the effort.


1-Dependent-helper does ALL the effort. Patient does none of the effort to 

complete the activity. Or, the assistance of 2 or more helpers is required for 

the patient to complete the  


    activity.


If activity was not attempted, code reason:


7-Patient Refused.


9-Not Applicable-not attempted and the patient did not perform the activity 

before the current illness, exacerbation or injury.


10-Not Attempted due to Environmental Limitations-(lack of equipment, weather 

restraints, etc.).


88-Not Attempted due to Medical Conditions or Safety Concerns.

(1) Acute heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and diastolic dysfunction


Assessment & Plan:  Symptomatically improved.  She is on carvedilol, Entresto 

and spironolactone.





(2) Cardiomyopathy


Assessment & Plan:  Her most recent previous echocardiogram from 2021 showed 

mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction.  Now she has severe left ventricular

systolic dysfunction.  She may need an ischemic evaluation once she recovers 

from her COVID.  We may also want to consider a LifeVest prior to discharge.





(3) Primary hypertension


Assessment & Plan:  Blood pressure is reasonably controlled with the present 

combination of medications.  If anything, at times she is running on the low 

side.





(4) Mixed hyperlipidemia


Assessment & Plan:  It appears as though she may have been on both atorvastatin 

and fenofibrate at home.  I will resume the atorvastatin.  I will hold off on 

restarting fenofibrate due to her acute debility with potentially increased risk

for medication interactions between the atorvastatin and fenofibrate.

likely a low-output fistula.  About 30-40% of these will close spontaneously in 

a few months.  I think she should continue eating, we will continue monitoring 

output and see if it can close on its own.  If there is not good enough 

improvement then at some point 


will discuss need for strict NPO and TPN.  Either way I talked to her about 

nutrition and how this will need to be optimized before we attempt anything 

surgical.  I also told her we would stop her Lovenox (for DVT prophylaxis) 

because she may be bleeding, based


on her fistula output and as long as she walks she doesn't need the Lovenox.  Pt

encouraged to ambulate (a lot in her room) and work with PT.

Progress Note


HPI: This is a very complex 75yoWF who had been admitted **** due to **** and 

found down at home for 18 hours after HH nurse found her (she had no phone 

access and her life alert had been turned off) following a 3 week hospital 

course at **** (****/2022) due to **** hospital stay on **** 

due to confusion from sepsis from pelvic abscess required drainage by IR due to 

ileostomy reversal leak and subsequent abscess formation. She has a h/o subtotal

colectomy with ileostomy on **** due to pseudomembranous colitis causing 

ischemic bowel and that was performed by Dr ****. The recent ileostomy reversal 

was performed by Dr ****. She was admitted for observation and IVF 

on med-surg and promptly moved to IRF due to weakness and need to strengthen 

prior to DC but shortly after she arrived in **** she was found to have a fever 

of 38.6 and tachycardia of 142 and sepsis w/u initiated and found to have COVID 

infection with lactic acidosis not due to sepsis so the decision was made to 

move to ICU. Pt was placed on levofloxacin for sepsis and pelvic abscess. Pt has

hx of CHF, so spironolactone and lasix were also started. Lovenox started for 

DVT prophylaxis. General surgery was consulted for central line placement and 

possible drain removal. Dr. **** placed central line, but drain was not removed 

at this time. Pt remained stable in **** and on **** she was transferred to 4th 

floor and remained in isolation for COVID. Pt was not requiring oxygen at this 

time. On **** pts colostomy bag began to leak and general surgery was consulted.

Dr. **** saw pt and plans to remove the drain at some point. Since pt is not 

requiring oxygen and vitals are within normal limits, decision was made to move 

pt to inpatient rehab facility. Chemistry panel showed corrected calcium of 7.5,

so pt started on Tums three times daily and vitamin D level will be checked. Pt 

will remain in isolation until **** according to hospitals infection control 

specialist. Goals of care are rehabilitation and strength training to get pt 

closer to baseline. Pt medically stable for d/c to IRF today .

OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF SERVICE:  ****



ATTENDING **** PHYSICIAN:

****.



ATTENDING PHYSICIAN:

Dr. ****.



INDICATIONS FOR PROCEDURE:

The patient is a 75-year-old female with multiple medical history.  She has had

a history of Clostridium difficile, toxic megacolon requiring a subtotal

colectomy.  This was later reversed.  She was very weak and was in long-term

acute care hospital for some amount of time.  She again became weak and fell at

home.  She was found to be COVID positive.  She is tachycardic and has very poor

peripheral venous circulation and will require a central venous catheter.



DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:

Chest and neck were prepped and draped in a standard surgical fashion.  A 1%

lidocaine was used to anesthetize the left subclavian region.  The left

subclavian vein was then cannulated with drawing of venous blood and the

guidewire was then inserted without any resistance.  Cannulating needle was

removed and a skin incision was made using 11 blade.  A tract was then created

using a venous dilator and through this opening, a triple lumen central venous

catheter was placed over the guidewire using the Seldinger technique.  The

guidewire was removed and all three ports drew venous blood and saline pushed in

without any resistance.  Catheter was then sutured to the skin using interrupted

3-0 silk sutures, cleaned, and covered with Op-Site.



The patient tolerated the procedure well.  We will get a post procedure chest

x-ray.

ADL-Prior Level of Function


****: Activities may be completed with or without assistive devices.





6-Indepedent-patient completes the activity by him/herself with no assistance 

from a helper.


5-Set-up or Clean-up Assistance-helper sets up or cleans up; patient completes 

activity. **** assists only prior to ****  


    following the activity.


4-Supervision or Touching Assistance-helper provides verbal cues and/or 

touching/steadying and/or contact guard assistance as patient completes 

activity. Assistance may be provided   


    throughout the activity or intermittently.


3-Partial/Moderate Assistance-helper does LESS **** **** the effort. **** 

lifts, holds or supports trunk or limbs, but provides less than half the effort.


2-Substantial/Maximal Assistance-helper does MORE **** **** the effort. **** 

lifts or holds trunk or limbs and provides more than half the effort.


1-Dependent-helper does ALL the effort. Patient does none of the effort to 

complete the activity. Or, the assistance of 2 or more helpers is required for 

the patient to complete the  


    activity.

7-Patient Refused.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:

The patient is a 75-year-old female with an extensive past medical history.  She

had a significant Clostridium difficile colic causing toxic megacolon requiring

a subtotal colectomy and an end ileostomy.  This was done at **** Hospital. 

She then underwent a reversal of the colostomy.  She then did develop a pelvic

abscess, which was drained by interventional radiology.  She also did develop a

fistula as well.  She was admitted for weakness and found to be COVID positive. 

She also has a very poor peripheral venous circulation and is febrile and

tachycardic and will require a central venous catheter.



PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Clostridium difficile toxic megacolon, gastroesophageal reflux disease,

degenerative joint disease, rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, hypothyroid, history

of ovarian cancer, atrial fibrillation, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension.



PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:

Exploratory laparotomy, subtotal colectomy, colostomy reversal, laparoscopic

cholecystectomy, total hysterectomy, nephrectomy, and tonsillectomy.



ALLERGIES:

PENICILLIN.



MEDICATIONS:

Amitriptyline 100 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg daily, carvedilol 25 mg daily,

cetirizine 10 mg daily, famotidine 20 mg daily, fenofibrate 160 mg daily, iron

325 mg b.i.d., latanoprost eyedrops daily, leflunomide 20 mg every other day,

levothyroxine 125 mcg daily, and oxybutynin 5 mg b.i.d.



SOCIAL HISTORY:

Negative smoke and negative alcohol.



FAMILY HISTORY:

Noncontributory.



REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:

This a slightly thin-appearing female, currently in no acute distress.  She is

not experiencing any shortness of breath or difficulty in breathing.  No cough

or sputum production.  She is experiencing no nausea, vomiting; however, does

not have much of an appetite.  She states that she does have bowel movements and

does have a gastrointestinal fistula with minimal drainage.  She is having some

fevers and has lost weight since her colon resection.

COMPARISON: ****





Unenhanced images of the liver and spleen reveal no focal

abdominal wall with small amount of gas and fluid along the

but otherwise unremarkable.

rectum suggestive of proctocolitis. There is a small amount of


fluid within the anterior abdominal wall incision site, however,


no other focal fluid collection is seen to indicate abscess.

rate 122 blood pressure 70s.  After the bolus her heart rate is down to 105 her 

blood pressure is up to 11****.  Oxygen 100% on room air.  Respiratory rate is

the umbilicus.  I will put her on cefepime and IV Flagyl to include anaerobic

vancomycin for suspected C. difficile colitis.  We will collect a stool sample a

s soon as possible.   She does wear a LifeVest started on **** for severe

echocardiogram ****.  She does wish to remain full CODE STATUS.  Spoke to

Unenhanced images of the liver and spleen reveal no focal


abnormality. No pancreatic, adrenal gland or left renal


abnormality is identified. Right kidney is absent. Gallbladder


has been removed. There is fluid distention of colon with diffuse


mural thickening. There is extensively thickened sigmoid colon


and rectal walls. Surgical findings are seen in the anterior


abdominal wall with small amount of gas and fluid along the


midline incision site. Unenhanced urinary bladder is distended


but otherwise unremarkable.





IMPRESSION: Extensive mural thickening of the distal colon and


rectum suggestive of proctocolitis. There is a small amount of


fluid within the anterior abdominal wall incision site, however,


no other focal fluid collection is seen to indicate abscess.

Progress Note


Hospital course:


**** **** 75y/o who was admitted on **** after presenting to the ER 

due to diarrhea and generalized weakness. She was found to have c.diff and was 

started on oral vancomycin. Surgery was consulted for fistula present from 

ileostomy reversal done on ****. Abdominal CT done showed thickening of colon

wall but no evidence of fecal fluid collection or abscess. AKI also present on 

admission due to dehydration from the diarrhea, treated with IVF. PT and OT 

started on ****. Metabolic acidosis found on **** and she was then started on 

sodium bicarb tablets. Has received treatment for the c.diff w/ vancomycin and 

electrolytes have been managed throughout course of stay. Fistula has had 

minimal drainage. She will be hopefully transferring to Carthage to a swing bed 

today.

PROCEDURE: CT abdomen and pelvis without contrast.

INDICATION:  Periumbilical abdominal pain



COMPARISON: ****



Unenhanced images of the liver and spleen reveal no focal

abnormality. No pancreatic, adrenal gland or left renal

abnormality is identified. Right kidney is absent. Gallbladder

has been removed. There is fluid distention of colon with diffuse

mural thickening. There is extensively thickened sigmoid colon

and rectal walls. Surgical findings are seen in the anterior

abdominal wall with small amount of gas and fluid along the

midline incision site. Unenhanced urinary bladder is distended

but otherwise unremarkable.



IMPRESSION: Extensive mural thickening of the distal colon and

rectum suggestive of proctocolitis. There is a small amount of

fluid within the anterior abdominal wall incision site, however,

no other focal fluid collection is seen to indicate abscess.

Assessment/Plan


Admission Dx

Admission Status:  Inpatient Order (span 2 midnights)


Reason for Inpatient Admission:  


Patient admission is necessary for the monitoring of vital signs, drug


toxicity, and the need for blood products.


Assessment & Plan


Sepsis secondary to C. Diff Infection - Continue vancomycin and monitor for 

toxicity or worsening of abdominal symptoms. Consider fecal transplant.


Anemia - Transfusion to be administered after type and screen results and iron 

studies are obtained. Consider imaging studies or colonoscopy to locate source 

of acute bleed.


A. Fib - continue medical management


Diabetes mellitus - continue medical management and closely monitor glucose 

levels


Hypertension - continue medical management


Hypothyroidism - continue levothyroxine


Mixed Hyperlipidemia - continue atorvastatin
